channel.title: LSAT Logic in Everyday Life
channel.itunes:subtitle: Brought to you by The Princeton Review
channel.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
channel.itunes:summary: A weekly podcast that applies the logic of the LSAT to politics, advertisements, and conventional wisdom.
channel.description: A weekly podcast that applies the logic of the LSAT to politics, advertisements, and conventional wisdom

item.title: Genes and Walgreen's
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Should drug stores sell genetic testing kits directly to consumers?
item.itunes:summary: This week, we look at the arguments for and against widespread use of at-home genetic testing.
item.description: This week, we look at the arguments for and against widespread use of at-home genetic testing.

item.title: Donation Sensation
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Are text message donations the most immediate way to give?
item.itunes:summary: In the wake of the earthquake in Haiti, we look at the pros and cons of donating via text message.
item.description: In the wake of the earthquake in Haiti, we look at the pros and cons of donating via text message.

item.title: See Right Through You
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Will full body scanners make us (feel) safe?
item.itunes:summary: In this week's podcast, the first of 2010, we look at the security vs. privacy argument around the implementation of full body scanners.
item.description: In this week's podcast, the first of 2010, we look at the security vs. privacy argument around the implementation of full body scanners.

item.title: Swine Fluent
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: To vaccinate or not to vaccinate?
item.itunes:summary: Bill Maher was attacked this week for warning people away from the swine flu. In this podcast, we look at his argument and try to understand why people are wary of vaccinating against H1N1.
item.description: Bill Maher was attacked this week for warning people away from the swine flu. In this podcast, we look at his argument and try to understand why people are wary of vaccinating against H1N1.

item.title: OK in Moderation
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: All we need to know about high fructose corn syrup?
item.itunes:summary: This week we look at new commercials combatting high fructose corn syrup's bad reputation.
item.description: This week we look at new commercials combatting high fructose corn syrup's bad reputation.

item.title: Rhyme and Reason
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: President Obama's appeal to rationality and emotion in the health care debate.
item.itunes:summary: This week, we unpack the structure of Obama's speech to Congress on the issue of health care reform.
item.description: This week, we unpack the structure of Obama's speech to Congress on the issue of health care reform.

item.title: Voir Dire Straits
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: First-person account of jury selection.
item.itunes:summary: This week, we look at the assumptions that go into jury selection.
item.description: This week, we look at the assumptions that go into jury selection.

item.title: Suit Yourself
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: The Great Swimsuit Controversy of 2009
item.itunes:summary: This week, we look at FINA's decision to ban polyurethane swimsuits in the wake of the Rome World Championship Swimming controversy.
item.description: This week, we look at FINA's decision to ban polyurethane swimsuits in the wake of the Rome World Championship Swimming controversy.

item.title: Jet Setting
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: To fund or not to fund?
item.itunes:summary: This week, one of the more interesting political debates of the year resolved in the Senate. We look at both sides of the argument about funding the F-22 fighter.
item.description: This week, one of the more interesting political debates of the year resolved in the Senate. We look at both sides of the argument about funding the F-22 fighter.

item.title: Logic Headache
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Should we be putting down the Tylenol?
item.itunes:summary: This week, discuss a new recommendation from a federal panel that Vicodin and Percocet be banned because of the dangers of acetaminophen overdose, and what that means for other drugs containing acetaminophen.
item.description: This week, discuss a new recommendation from a federal panel that Vicodin and Percocet be banned because of the dangers of acetaminophen overdose, and what that means for other drugs containing acetaminophen.

item.title: Nic Fit
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Has the U.S. Congress finally stuck it to 'Big Tobacco?'
item.itunes:summary: This week, we look at new legislation passed this week placing regulatory control of the tobacco industry in the hands of the FDA.
item.description: This week, we look at new legislation passed this week placing regulatory control of the tobacco industry in the hands of the FDA.

item.title: Sun Screed
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Is a year of daily sun exposure really like a week of unprotected sun at the beach?
item.itunes:summary: This week, we unpack the comparison flaw in an Aveeno commercial.
item.description: This week, we unpack the comparison flaw in an Aveeno commercial.

item.title: Brain Drain Stopper
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Will Google's new algorithm solve its brain-drain problem?
item.itunes:summary: This week, we look at a new algorith that Google is testing to determine which of its employees might be thinking about quitting.
item.description: This week, we look at a new algorith that Google is testing to determine which of its employees might be thinking about quitting.

item.title: Anti-Antioxidants
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Do antioxidants interfere with the benefits of exercise?
item.itunes:summary: This week, we look at potential flaws in a new study that purports to show that the benefits of exercise are blocked by antioxidant supplementation.
item.description: This week, we look at potential flaws in a new study that purports to show that the benefits of exercise are blocked by antioxidant supplementation.

item.title: The Logic of Dow
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: How should we interpret the DJIA?
item.itunes:summary: Monday saw the fifth largest single day point rally in the Dow Jones's history. We look at how the Dow is measured and the conclusions you can draw from it.
item.description: Monday saw the fifth largest single day point rally in the Dow Jones's history. We look at how the Dow is measured and the conclusions you can draw from it.

item.title: Sickly Sweet
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: The illogical world of artificial sweeteners and sugar substitutes.
item.itunes:summary: This week, we look at many of the arguments surrounding the safety and efficacy of sugar substitutes to learn important logic lessons.
item.description: This week, we look at many of the arguments surrounding the safety and efficacy of sugar substitutes to learn important logic lessons.

item.title: Working Stats
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Which unemployment rate statistic works?
item.itunes:summary: This week, we take a look at the U3 measurement of unemployment statistic in order to see how comparing statistics across time periods can lead to flawed conclusions.
item.description: This week, we take a look at the U3 measurement of unemployment statistic in order to see how comparing statistics across time periods can lead to flawed conclusions.

item.title: The Consuming Question
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Is Black Friday a sign of out-of-control consumerism?
item.itunes:summary: A Wal-Mart employee was crushed to death in a stampede of shoppers looking for door buster sales on Black Friday. This week, we look at the argument that this year's Black Friday is a sure sign that rampant consumerism is out of control.
item.description: A Wal-Mart employee was crushed to death in a stampede of shoppers looking for door buster sales on Black Friday. This week, we look at the argument that this year's Black Friday is a sure sign that rampant consumerism is out of control.

item.title: Sure of the Cure?
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Have scientists discovered a cure for AIDS?
item.itunes:summary: A man in Germany has no sign of HIV infection 600 days after a bone marrow transplant. This week, we explore part-to-whole flaws in the inference that an AIDS cure has been found.
item.description: A man in Germany has no sign of HIV infection 600 days after a bone marrow transplant. This week, we explore part-to-whole flaws in the inference that an AIDS cure has been found.

item.title: Listener Logic #13: Election Special
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Emails to the lsatpodcast@review.com Inbox
item.itunes:summary: For logic lovers, this election has been one for the books. In this week's episode, listeners take apart some of the campaign spin.
item.description: For logic lovers, this election has been one for the books. In this week's episode, listeners take apart some of the campaign spin.

item.title: Trial of This Century?
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Is the OJ verdict simply payback for his acquittal 13 years ago?
item.itunes:summary: This week, we look at the argument, made by OJ's lawyers, that the jury selection process was flawed in OJ's most recent trial.
item.description: This week, we look at the argument, made by OJ's lawyers, that the jury selection process was flawed in OJ's most recent trial.

item.title: It's the Stupid Economy
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: The logical questions to ask about any bailout proposal.
item.itunes:summary: This week, we scrutinize the bailout proposal from the perspective of an argument intended to Solve a Problem.
item.description: This week, we scrutinize the bailout proposal from the perspective of an argument intended to Solve a Problem.

item.title: Orderly Thinking
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Logic in the ER
item.itunes:summary: Doctors making decisions in the emergency room use critical thinking similar to the logic tested on the LSAT.
item.description: Doctors making decisions in the emergency room use critical thinking similar to the logic tested on the LSAT.

item.title: Binge and Surge
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: What can we learn from Michael Phelps's diet?
item.itunes:summary: There seems to be a significant interest in Phelps's 10,000 calorie-a-day diet. We look at the conclusions that some people are trying to draw from the details of his diet.
item.description: There seems to be a significant interest in Phelps's 10,000 calorie-a-day diet. We look at the conclusions that some people are trying to draw from the details of his diet.

item.title: Listener Logic #12
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Emails to the lsatpodcast@review.com inbox.
item.itunes:summary: 1) Does circumcision prevent the spread of HiV? 2) Cohabitation correlated with higher divorce rates? 3) Have girls really caught up to boys in their math skills? 4) How do we make logical decisions in everyday life?
item.description: 1) Does circumcision prevent the spread of HiV? 2) Cohabitation correlated with higher divorce rates? 3) Have girls really caught up to boys in their math skills? 4) How do we make logical decisions in everyday life?

item.title: Alienated
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Should we believe in aliens because an astronaut tells us to?
item.itunes:summary: This week, we look at arguments by authority as we discuss astronaut Edgar Mitchell's claim that aliens have visited Earth.
item.description: This week, we look at arguments by authority as we discuss astronaut Edgar Mitchell's claim that aliens have visited Earth.

item.title: Ripe for the Picking Apart
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: What's the real cause of the Salmonella outbreak?
item.itunes:summary: After pointing the finger at tomatoes and causing over $100 million dollars of loss in that industry, government officials are turning their attention to other possible causes of the Salmonella outbreak, giving us a prime opportunity to see the real world consequences of jumping to causal conclusions.
item.description: After pointing the finger at tomatoes and causing over $100 million dollars of loss in that industry, government officials are turning their attention to other possible causes of the Salmonella outbreak, giving us a prime opportunity to see the real world consequences of jumping to causal conclusions.

item.title: Patience, Patients
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Scientists cured cancer in one man--how do we interpret the results?
item.itunes:summary: This week, scientists cloned one man's immune cells to help cure his melanoma. We look at ways in which the study can be built out to draw broad conclusions about the general cancer patient population.
item.description: This week, scientists cloned one man's immune cells to help cure his melanoma. We look at ways in which the study can be built out to draw broad conclusions about the general cancer patient population.

item.title: Lessons From the Heart
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: What can we learn from Tim Russert's early death?
item.itunes:summary: This week, we look at the assumptions and caveats built into the Framingham Risk Assessment Tool, designed to predict the likelihood of coronary disease symptoms.
item.description: This week, we look at the assumptions and caveats built into the Framingham Risk Assessment Tool, designed to predict the likelihood of coronary disease symptoms.

item.title: Hold the Phone
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Do cell phones cause brain tumors?
item.itunes:summary: This week, we look at methodological flaws in studies purporting to demonstrate cell phone safety.
item.description: This week, we look at methodological flaws in studies purporting to demonstrate cell phone safety.

item.title: Pressing the Press Secretary
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Reactions to Scott McCellan's new book, What Happened
item.itunes:summary: This week, we look at the attacks on Scott McClellan's character and motivations in the wake of his new White House expose.
item.description: This week, we look at the attacks on Scott McClellan's character and motivations in the wake of his new White House expose.

item.title: Wedlock Gridlock
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Did the California Supreme Court put an end to the same sex marriage debate?
item.itunes:summary: This week, the California Supreme Court ruled Proposition 22 to be unconstitutional. In this week's podcast, we discuss the arguments surrounding the court's decision.
item.description: This week, the California Supreme Court ruled Proposition 22 to be unconstitutional. In this week's podcast, we discuss the arguments surrounding the court's decision.

item.title: Video Game Theory
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Do violent video games cause violent behavior?
item.itunes:summary: The release of Grand Theft Auto IV from Rockstar games sparked predictable outrage at the level of violence, gore, and sex, but is that outrage justified?
item.description: The release of Grand Theft Auto IV from Rockstar games sparked predictable outrage at the level of violence, gore, and sex, but is that outrage justified?

item.title: The Price is Rice
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Analyzing the run on rice.
item.itunes:summary: Was this week's run on rice due to panicky misperceptions about American food supply, or was it a reaction to the rising price?
item.description: Was this week's run on rice due to panicky misperceptions about American food supply, or was it a reaction to the rising price?

item.title: Listener Logic #11
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Emails to the lsatpodcast@review.com Inbox.
item.itunes:summary: 1) The ABC Democratic primary debate; 2) Single sex schools in Georgia; 3) Percentages and Numbers flaws with article about iPhone users; 4) Personal appeals to Iraqis.
item.description: 1) The ABC Democratic primary debate; 2) Single sex schools in Georgia; 3) Percentages and Numbers flaws with article about iPhone users; 4) Personal appeals to Iraqis.

item.title: Autism Awareness
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: The debate over the link between vaccines and autism.
item.itunes:summary: Autism Awareness Day brought the debate about a possible connection between vaccines and autism to the national spotlight. We look at the terms of the debate.
item.description: Autism Awareness Day brought the debate about a possible connection between vaccines and autism to the national spotlight. We look at the terms of the debate.

item.title: Cough it Up
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Does taking money from tobacco companies taint lung cancer research?
item.itunes:summary: This week, we look at a 2006 study on preventing lung cancer that was recently revealed to have been funded by grants from a large tobacco company.
item.description: This week, we look at a 2006 study on preventing lung cancer that was recently revealed to have been funded by grants from a large tobacco company.

item.title: What Gives?
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Does giving away your money make you happy?
item.itunes:summary: This week, we look at an article that purports to demonstrate that spending money on others causes happiness more than spending money on oneself. We look at ways to strengthen and weaken this causal conclusion.
item.description: This week, we look at an article that purports to demonstrate that spending money on others causes happiness more than spending money on oneself. We look at ways to strengthen and weaken this causal conclusion.

item.title: No "There" There
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Empty arguments take over the media.
item.itunes:summary: An LSAT Logic take on Spitzer, Ferraro, and Rev. Wright.
item.description: An LSAT Logic take on Spitzer, Ferraro, and Rev. Wright.

item.title: Listener Logic #10
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Emails to the lsatpodcast@review.com Inbox.
item.itunes:summary: 1) Guns on campuses; 2) Universal Health Care; 3) Poverty and weight correlation; 4) "It's not mean if it's true."
item.description: 1) Guns on campuses; 2) Universal Health Care; 3) Poverty and weight correlation; 4) "It's not mean if it's true."

item.title: Fat Chance
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Is restricting access to restaurants an effective way to address obesity?
item.itunes:summary: This week, a bill was proposed (and subsequently rejected) in the state legislature in MIssissippi that would ban obese people from restaurants. We look at why the bill fails to address the problem of obesity.
item.description: This week, a bill was proposed (and subsequently rejected) in the state legislature in MIssissippi that would ban obese people from restaurants. We look at why the bill fails to address the problem of obesity.

item.title: The Heart of a Super Fan
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Does watching the Super Bowl increase the risk of a cardiac emergency?
item.itunes:summary: A new study warns about the risks associated with rising stress levels during tense sports events. We take apart the argument for watching or skipping the Super Bowl.
item.description: A new study warns about the risks associated with rising stress levels during tense sports events. We take apart the argument for watching or skipping the Super Bowl.

item.title: Changing the Game
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Will iTunes movie rentals begin a paradigm shift for digital movies?
item.itunes:summary: The iTunes Music Store changed the way we discuss, purchase, and create music. Many analysts argue that the iTunes movie rentals will do the same for movies. We look at the strengths and weaknesses of the comparison.
item.description: The iTunes Music Store changed the way we discuss, purchase, and create music. Many analysts argue that the iTunes movie rentals will do the same for movies. We look at the strengths and weaknesses of the comparison.

item.title: R we or Rn't we?
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Should economists raise the specter of recession?
item.itunes:summary: This week we discuss why economists don't flat out say whether or not there is a recession, and we look at arguments that discuss whether or not they should.
item.description: This week we discuss why economists don't flat out say whether or not there is a recession, and we look at arguments that discuss whether or not they should.

item.title: Changing "Change"
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Equivocation in the 2008 campaign?
item.itunes:summary: In the race to the presidential nomination, everyone's talking about change, but using the word in different ways to manipulate the argument in favor of their position. On the LSAT, we call that equivocation.
item.description: In the race to the presidential nomination, everyone's talking about change, but using the word in different ways to manipulate the argument in favor of their position. On the LSAT, we call that equivocation."

item.title: 80 Men Out
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Dealing with the repercussions of the Mitchell Report.
item.itunes:summary: Faced with the evidence of rampant abuse of performance-enhancing drugs in Major League Baseball, the country is grappling with two questions: "Why does it matter?" and "What now?"
item.description: Faced with the evidence of rampant abuse of performance-enhancing drugs in Major League Baseball, the country is grappling with two questions: "Why does it matter?" and "What now?"

item.title: Mitt's JFK Moment
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Two ways to address religion in politics.
item.itunes:summary: Pundits and journalists began drawing comparisons to JFK before Romney even gave his speech on religion - now they're dealing with their own comparison flaws.
item.description: Pundits and journalists began drawing comparisons to JFK before Romney even gave his speech on religion - now they're dealing with their own comparison flaws.

item.title: Listener Logic #9
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Emails to the lsatpodcast@review.com inbox.
item.itunes:summary: 1) American math/science scores paradox; 2) Necessary and Sufficient mixup in Anthropology class; 3) Strike arguments; 4) Dirty Dancing.
item.description: 1) American math/science scores paradox; 2) Necessary and Sufficient mixup in Anthropology class; 3) Strike arguments; 4) Dirty Dancing.

item.title: The Georgia Rain
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Did prayer cause this week's rainfall in Georgia?
item.itunes:summary: In the midst of an historic drought, Georgia's governor called for a prayer vigil on Tuesday, then it rained on Wednesday. In this podcast, we take a close look at the argument that prayer caused the rain relief.
item.description: In the midst of an historic drought, Georgia's governor called for a prayer vigil on Tuesday, then it rained on Wednesday. In this podcast, we take a close look at the argument that prayer caused the rain relief.

item.title: Told You So!
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Proof of liberal media bias?
item.itunes:summary: Conservatives point to a recenet Harvard study about press coverage of the primary election candidates as proof of liberal media bias. We take a look at the methodology of the study to determine if it really proves a liberal bias in the media.
item.description: Conservatives point to a recenet Harvard study about press coverage of the primary election candidates as proof of liberal media bias. We take a look at the methodology of the study to determine if it really proves a liberal bias in the media.

item.title: Of Mice and Mazes
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Hypertension drugs prevent Alzheimer's in mice, but will it work on humans?
item.itunes:summary: This week, a study demonstrated that certain blood pressure medications might prevent Alzheimer's disease in mice. We consider reasons why people hoping to stave off Alzheimer's disease might not want to run out and convince their doctors to give them prescriptions.
item.description: This week, a study demonstrated that certain blood pressure medications might prevent Alzheimer's disease in mice. We consider reasons why people hoping to stave off Alzheimer's disease might not want to run out and convince their doctors to give them prescriptions.

item.title: The Maine Point
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Trouble for a Maine school district.
item.itunes:summary: The decision by a Portland school board to allow a middle school health clinic to prescribe oral contraceptives has set off a firestorm of debate. We look at the arguments and their underlying assumptions.
item.description: The decision by a Portland school board to allow a middle school health clinic to prescribe oral contraceptives has set off a firestorm of debate. We look at the arguments and their underlying assumptions.

item.title: The Wrong Conversation
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: The logic mess surrounding Graeme Frost and the S-CHIP bill.
item.itunes:summary: Many people are up in arms over the smearing of 12-year-old Graeme Frost, but are there legitimate questions about using a child as a spokesperson for a complex piece of legislation?
item.description: Many people are up in arms over the smearing of 12-year-old Graeme Frost, but are there legitimate questions about using a child as a spokesperson for a complex piece of legislation?

item.title: Listener Logic #8
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Emails to the lsatpodcast@review.com Inbox
item.itunes:summary: 1) Are Christians uglier than non-Christians? 2) Where's the logic in music piracy? 3) Cliche: It's always the last place you look.
item.description: 1) Are Christians uglier than non-Christians? 2) Where's the logic in music piracy? 3) Cliche: It's always the last place you look.

item.title: Meteor Madness
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Cause vs. coincidence in the Peruvian Meteor Mystery.
item.itunes:summary: This week we look at the logic behind the Peruvian meteor story, as experts tried to track down exactly what happened and what the results were.
item.description: This week we look at the logic behind the Peruvian meteor story, as experts tried to track down exactly what happened and what the results were.

item.title: Cut to the Tase
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Did University of Florida police go too far?
item.itunes:summary: This week we look at the University of Florida security enforcement's decision to taser a student who they believed was not acting appropriately during a John Kerry forum.
item.description: This week we look at the University of Florida security enforcement's decision to taser a student who they believed was not acting appropriately during a John Kerry forum.

item.title: The Lowdown on Lonely
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: How does loneliness affect health?
item.itunes:summary: This week we take a close look at a recent study that purports to explain the link between loneliness and inflammation.
item.description: This week we take a close look at a recent study that purports to explain the link between loneliness and inflammation.

item.title: Iraq Stat Attack
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: An LSAT Logic in Everday Life Guide to Evaluating Statistics in anticipation of the Iraq Stat Attack.
item.itunes:summary: Understanding definitions, statistical comparisons, and parameters in order to be skeptical judges of purportedly objective numbers.
item.description: Understanding definitions, statistical comparisons, and parameters in order to be skeptical judges of purportedly objective numbers.

item.title: America, the Beautiful
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: The logic of beauty pageant contestants
item.itunes:summary: This week, we forgo the trainwreck answer from a recent beauty pageant but take apart the logic of the second try.
item.description: This week, we forgo the trainwreck answer from a recent beauty pageant but take apart the logic of the second try.

item.title: Breaking the Chains
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Has the iPhone been freed?
item.itunes:summary: Of the many groups who have unlocked the iPhone this week, 17 year-old George Hotz has received the most attention. We look at arguments calling him a hero or a criminal.
item.description: Of the many groups who have unlocked the iPhone this week, 17 year-old George Hotz has received the most attention. We look at arguments calling him a hero or a criminal.

item.title: Listener Logic #7
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: E-mails to the lsatpodcast@review.com Inbox.
item.itunes:summary: 1) Superstitions in Romania; 2) Cliched comeback: That's Old News!; 3) Addicts and Rationality
item.description: 1) Superstitions in Romania; 2) Cliched comeback: That's Old News!; 3) Addicts and Rationality

item.title: Pole Dance
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Who owns the North Pole?
item.itunes:summary: This week we tackle flaws in the Law of the Sea.
item.description: This week we tackle flaws in the Law of the Sea.

item.title: O Really?
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Bill O'Reilly teaches us a lesson in part-to-whole comparison flaws.
item.itunes:summary: Part-to-whole comparison flaws can be more complicated than they seem at first. We look at Bill O'Reilly's attack on dailykos.com to point out some of the subtleties.
item.description: Part-to-whole comparison flaws can be more complicated than they seem at first. We look at Bill O'Reilly's attack on dailykos.com to point out some of the subtleties.

item.title: Listener Logic #6
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: E-mails to the lsatpodcast@review.com Inbox.
item.itunes:summary: 1) A response to the Potter podcast. 2) Cliches from Dr. Phil. 3) Believing in Science. 4) Splenda and sugar. 5) Prime Beef.
item.description: 1) A response to the Potter podcast. 2) Cliches from Dr. Phil. 3) Believing in Science. 4) Splenda and sugar. 5) Prime Beef.

item.title: Spoiler Alert!
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Does the New York Times hate kids?
item.itunes:summary: This week, we look at the claim that publishing early reviews of the new Harry Potter book means the New York Times hate kids.
item.description: This week, we look at the claim that publishing early reviews of the new Harry Potter book means the New York Times hate kids.

item.title: The Soccer Messiah
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Will Beckham's celebrity influence American's view of soccer?
item.itunes:summary: This week we look at claims that David Beckham's U.S. arrival will take soccer to a new level in the States as well as counterclaims that he will have little influence.
item.description: This week we look at claims that David Beckham's U.S. arrival will take soccer to a new level in the States as well as counterclaims that he will have little influence.

item.title: Let's Talk About Myth Busting
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: The difference between busting a myth and calling it into question.
item.itunes:summary: This week a study was touted as disproving the stereotype that women talk more than men, but the methodology of the study might limit the applicability of its conclusions.
item.description: This week a study was touted as disproving the stereotype that women talk more than men, but the methodology of the study might limit the applicability of its conclusions.

item.title: Coulter Confrontation
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Confusion and counterarguments on cable news.
item.itunes:summary: This week we take apart the awkward interaction between Ann Coulter and Elizabeth Edwards on MSNBC.
item.description: This week we take apart the awkward interaction between Ann Coulter and Elizabeth Edwards on MSNBC.

item.title: First-Born Fortune
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Is nature or nurture (or both) behind birth order effects on intelligence?
item.itunes:summary: This week, we take a look at the study behind headlines touting the higher intelligence of first-born children.
item.description: This week, we take a look at the study behind headlines touting the higher intelligence of first-born children.

item.title: Listener Logic #5
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Emails to the lsatpodcast@review.com inbox.
item.itunes:summary: 1)If it looks like a green duck; 2) Life is unfair; 3) A matter of taste; and 4) That's the way it's always been done
item.description: If it looks like a green duck; 2) Life is unfair; 3) A matter of taste; and 4) That's the way it's always been done

item.title: Point of View
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Is Google's new Street View feaeture an invasion of privacy?
item.itunes:summary: New technology can bring great new benefits but also potential problems. We take apart Google's argument that its Street View feature is not an invasion of privacy.
item.description: New technology can bring great new benefits but also potential problems. We take apart Google's argument that its Street View feature is not an invasion of privacy

item.title: Quarantine Quagmire
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Should Andrew Speaker have boarded that plane?
item.itunes:summary: This week we look at the ethical principles involved in Andrew Speaker's decision to board an international flight after being told by health officials to stay put.
item.description: This week we look at the ethical principles involved in Andrew Speaker's decision to board an international flight after being told by health officials to stay put.

item.title: It's Just Gas
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Why are so many Americans travelling this weekend, even with gas prices so high?
item.itunes:summary: This week we try to resolve the paradox: Americans are concerned about increasing gas prices, which are much higher this year than last year, and yet more Americans will be travelling this weekend than last Memorial Day.
item.description: This week we try to resolve the paradox: Americans are concerned about increasing gas prices, which are much higher this year than last year, and yet more Americans will be travelling this weekend than last Memorial Day.

item.title: Maybe I Would Jump Off a Bridge
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Listeners submit their favorite illogical comebacks.
item.itunes:summary: This week we look at some cliche retorts.
item.description: This week we look at some cliche retorts.

item.title: On the Books
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Do the shrinking book review sections in newspapers signify the death of literary culture?
item.itunes:summary: This week we examine the discourse surrounding newspaper book reviews versus litblogs on the heels of the decision by the Atlanta Journal-Constitution and other newspapers to cut back on their book review sections.
item.description: This week we examine the discourse surrounding newspaper book reviews versus litblogs on the heels of the decision by the Atlanta Journal-Constitution and other newspapers to cut back on their book review sections.

item.title: We'll Always Have Paris
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Should Hilton serve hard time?
item.itunes:summary: Paris Hilton has been sentenced to 45 days in jail. This week we look at arguments that her celebrity status affected her case.
item.description: Paris Hilton has been sentenced to 45 days in jail. This week we look at arguments that her celebrity status affected her case.

item.title: All Abuzz
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: The case of the disappearing bees.
item.itunes:summary: The United States agricultural sector is suffering from a bee die-off that now appears to have global implications. We look at some of the proposed causes, including cell phone radiation and a new fungus.
item.description: The United States agricultural sector is suffering from a bee die-off that now appears to have global implications. We look at some of the proposed causes, including cell phone radiation and a new fungus.

item.title: What's Your Angle?
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: The problem of preconceived notions.
item.itunes:summary: This week, we look at three separate events that had people drawing conclusions from preconceived notions without paying close attention to the premises.
item.description: This week, we look at three separate events that had people drawing conclusions from preconceived notions without paying close attention to the premises.

item.title: Eye on Imus
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: "Free country" and "what about" arguments.
item.itunes:summary: This week, we look at the controvery surrounding Don Imus and the logic behind the punditry.
item.description: This week, we look at the controvery surrounding Don Imus and the logic behind the punditry.

item.title: Hard Cell
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: The FCC refuses to lift the ban on cell phone use in the skies.
item.itunes:summary: This week, we look at the FCC's termination of their inquiry into cell phone use on airplanes and we see if their evidence is sufficient to reach their conclusion.
item.description: This week, we look at the FCC's termination of their inquiry into cell phone use on airplanes and we see if their evidence is sufficient to reach their conclusion.

item.title: Cross Words
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Does mental exercise help stave off Alzheimer's Disease?
item.itunes:summary: This week, we look at claims from scientists that stimulating mental exercises such as frequent museum visits and crossword puzzles can help prevent mental degenerative diseases.
item.description: This week, we look at claims from scientists that stimulating mental exercises such as frequent museum visits and crossword puzzles can help prevent mental degenerative diseases.

item.title: Pet Peeved
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Is the pet food panic warranted?
item.itunes:summary: This week, Menu Foods announced an enormous recall of its wet pet food lines after reports of kidney failure. We look at some of the extreme conclusions that pet owners are making based on the latest scare.
item.description: This week, Menu Foods announced an enormous recall of its wet pet food lines after reports of kidney failure. We look at some of the extreme conclusions that pet owners are making based on the latest scare.

item.title: Listener Logic #4
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: E-mails to the lsatpodcast@review.com inbox
item.itunes:summary: Emails to the lsatpodcast@review.com Inbox. 1) Khalid Sheikh Mohammed and the truth about confessions 2) Gun control in Washington DC 3) How is business size related to labor shortages
item.description: Emails to the lsatpodcast@review.com Inbox. 1) Khalid Sheikh Mohammed and the truth about confessions 2) Gun control in Washington DC 3) How is business size related to labor shortages

item.title: Save the Day
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Should we extend Daylight Saving Time?
item.itunes:summary: Daylight Saving Time redistributes an hour, taking from the morning and giving to the evening. This week, we examine the argument for extending Daylight Saving Time.
item.description: Daylight Saving Time redistributes an hour, taking from the morning and giving to the evening. This week, we examine the argument for extending Daylight Saving Time.

item.title: Poll Dance
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: An LLIEDL guide to reading polls.
item.itunes:summary: With the horserace of 2008 already on, it's important to cast a critical eye on polls used by pundits for political purposes.
item.description: With the horserace of 2008 already on, it's important to cast a critical eye on polls used by pundits for political purposes.

item.title: Cocoa Nuts
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Will Cocoa Keep Us Young?
item.itunes:summary: Scientists at the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science presented the health benefits of cocoa flavanols, but the presentation and some of the research was sponsored by candy-makers Mars, Inc. Is that reason enough to doubt their conclusions?
item.description: Scientists at the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science presented the health benefits of cocoa flavanols, but the presentation and some of the research was sponsored by candy-makers Mars, Inc. Is that reason enough to doubt their conclusions?

item.title: Thoughts on 'Thoughts on Music'
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Should Digital Rights Management become a thing of the past?
item.itunes:summary: This week, we dissect Steve Jobs' open letter to the record labels.
item.description: This week, we dissect Steve Jobs' open letter to the record labels.

item.title: Gadget Ban!
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Can New Yorkers be trusted crossing city streets with iPods, cell phones, and BlackBerry's?
item.itunes:summary: This week we look at the explosion of arguments against NY State Senator Carl Kruger's proposed gadget ban.
item.description: This week we look at the explosion of arguments against NY State Senator Carl Kruger's proposed gadget ban.

item.title: Commercial Bowl
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: A look at the year's most anticipated ads.
item.itunes:summary: At over 5 million dollars per minute, there's a lot of pressure on Super Bowl commercials to do their job. But what is their job? A commercial is an argument, but how do we judge its reasoning?
item.description: At over 5 million dollars per minute, there's a lot of pressure on Super Bowl commercials to do their job. But what is their job? A commercial is an argument, but how do we judge its reasoning?

item.title: Measure for Measure
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: How do we judge the strength of our economy.
item.itunes:summary: 1)Measure for Measure: How do we judge the strength of our economy? President Bush says that the economy is growing and on the move. Senator Jim Webb believes the opposite to be true. We see how the indicators they choose skew their conclusions.
item.description: 1)Measure for Measure: How do we judge the strength of our economy? President Bush says that the economy is growing and on the move. Senator Jim Webb believes the opposite to be true. We see how the indicators they choose skew their conclusions.

item.title: Listener Logic #3
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Emails to the lsatpodcast@review.com inbox.
item.itunes:summary: 1) Natural is not the opposite of pollutant. 2) Industry funding is not sufficient to conclude bias 3) Arguments for and against mentioning God in the pledge of allegiance.
item.description: 1) Natural is not the opposite of pollutant. 2) Industry funding is not sufficient to conclude bias 3) Arguments for and against mentioning God in the pledge of allegiance.

item.title: Trust Augmentation
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Bush gambles big on preconditions and assumptions.
item.itunes:summary: This week we analyze Bush's argument for a troop increase, identifying its key features, its strengths and vulnerabilities, and the fundamental assumption that more troops will lead to more security.
item.description: This week we analyze Bush's argument for a troop increase, identifying its key features, its strengths and vulnerabilities, and the fundamental assumption that more troops will lead to more security.

item.title: Weather or Not
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Is global warming to blame for warm winter weather?
item.itunes:summary: Everyone's talking about the weather, and it's not just small talk. This week, we explore the logic of pinning the blame for this year's winter weather anomalies on global warming.
item.description: Everyone's talking about the weather, and it's not just small talk. This week, we explore the logic of pinning the blame for this year's winter weather anomalies on global warming.

item.title: Health Craze
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: What is causing the decline in breast cancer rates?
item.itunes:summary: Multiple reports this week attempt to pinpoint causes for breast cancer. We examine the strengths and weaknesses of these theories.
item.description: Multiple reports this week attempt to pinpoint causes for breast cancer. We examine the strengths and weaknesses of these theories.

item.title: What's Next?
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: The slippery slope of food regulation.
item.itunes:summary: New York City has banned trans fats in restaurants. Restaurant owners and libertarians object. We look at arguments for and against the ban, focusing on the slippery slope fallacy.
item.description: New York City has banned trans fats in restaurants. Restaurant owners and libertarians object. We look at arguments for and against the ban, focusing on the slippery slope fallacy.

item.title: True Colors
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: What makes a racist?
item.itunes:summary: The media is abuzz with accusations of racism, from Michael Richards to the New York City Police Department. We look at flaws on both sides of the accusations.
item.description: The media is abuzz with accusations of racism, from Michael Richards to the New York City Police Department. We look at flaws on both sides of the accusations.

item.title: Borat's Nest
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Do the lawsuits against the cultural satire have merit?
item.itunes:summary: Some people criticize the plaintiffs as being just out to make a buck. Others say that a release form is a release form and that should end the question. But maybe there are relevant factors being overlooked.
item.description: 1) Some people criticize the plaintiffs as being just out to make a buck. Others say that a release form is a release form and that should end the question. But maybe there are relevant factors being overlooked.

item.title: Listener Logic #2
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Emails to the lsatpodcast@review.com Inbox.
item.itunes:summary: 1) Part-to-whole flaws in election results spin; 2) Ahmanedinijad's Holocaust denial; 3) The "MacArthur' option and war analogies.
item.description: 1) Part-to-whole flaws in election results spin; 2) Ahmanedinijad's Holocaust denial; 3) The "MacArthur' option and war analogies

item.title: (Hypo)Critical Thinking
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Looking for the substance in the Haggard-Jones mess.
item.itunes:summary: The allegations against an Evangelical leader were meant to affect a Colorado ballot initiative, but they don't quite hit the target.
item.description: The allegations against an Evangelical leader were meant to affect a Colorado ballot initiative, but they don't quite hit the target.

item.title: Putting the Ad in Ad Hominem
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Do negative political ads go too far?
item.itunes:summary: Sometimes it's a fine line between an ad that substantively attacks an opponent's position and an ad that solely attacks an opponents character.
item.description: Sometimes it's a fine line between an ad that substantively attacks an opponent's position and an ad that solely attacks an opponents character.

item.title: Madonna and Child
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Should the pop icon adopt baby David?
item.itunes:summary: Andrea Peyser of the Washington Post chastises Madonna for attempting to adopt an African child; others cheer her for saving a life.
item.description: Andrea Peyser of the Washington Post chastises Madonna for attempting to adopt an African child; others cheer her for saving a life.

item.title: Hard-Hitting, Side-Splitting
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Is the Daily Show news, or is the news a joke?
item.itunes:summary: A new study claims that the Daily Show contains as much substance as traditional news programs, and bloggers are using it to confirm their conflicting opinions about the show.
item.description: A new study claims that the Daily Show contains as much substance as traditional news programs, and bloggers are using it to confirm their conflicting opinions about the show.

item.title: Foley-mania!
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: The actions of one congressman have set off a firestorm of debate.
item.itunes:summary: This week we focus on the logic behind arguments for and against Dennis Hastert resigning as Speaker of the House.
item.description: This week we focus on the logic behind arguments for and against Dennis Hastert resigning as Speaker of the House.

item.title: Shop Till You Drop
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Should compulsive shopping be considered a mental disorder?
item.itunes:summary: A recent study finds that men are equally as likely to suffer from compulsive shopping as women, and advocates including compulsive shopping in the official list of mental disorders.
item.description: A recent study finds that men are equally as likely to suffer from compulsive shopping as women, and advocates including compulsive shopping in the official list of mental disorders.

item.title: They Must Be on Drugs
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Will the new Wal-mart prescription plan benefit consumers?
item.itunes:summary: This week Wal-mart announced plans to offer $4 prescriptions on many generic drugs. We apply the logic of the LSAT to the argument that this will be a significant benefit to consumers.
item.description: This week Wal-mart announced plans to offer $4 prescriptions on many generic drugs. We apply the logic of the LSAT to the argument that this will be a significant benefit to consumers.

item.title: Hold the Toasts
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Do drinkers earn more money, or do people with money drink more?
item.itunes:summary: This week, in order to demonstrate ways in which causal arguments can go wrong we take apart the findings of a new study purporting to show that social drinking leads to an increase in income.
item.description: This week, in order to demonstrate ways in which causal arguments can go wrong we take apart the findings of a new study purporting to show that social drinking leads to an increase in income.

item.title: Before 9/11 Was a Premise
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: A historical event becomes an uber-premise.
item.itunes:summary: In the years since September 11, 2001, we have used the events that occurred that day to justify national, political, and individual conclusions, even when its relevance has been questionable.
item.description: In the years since September 11, 2001, we have used the events that occurred that day to justify national, political, and individual conclusions, even when its relevance has been questionable.

item.title: Listener Logic #1
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Arguments from listeners sent to lsatpodcast@review.com
item.itunes:summary: Ad Hominem Attacks on Judge Taylor, Questions About Analogies, Shortening the NFL Preseason
item.description: Ad Hominem Attacks on Judge Taylor, Questions About Analogies, Shortening the NFL Preseason

item.title: Unchartered Territory
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Statistical flaws in the case against charter schools.
item.itunes:summary: New statistics released this week demonstrate that charter schools are not an acceptable alternative to public schools. Or do they?
item.description: New statistics released this week demonstrate that charter schools are not an acceptable alternative to public schools. Or do they?

item.title: The Pluto Principle
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Does the new definition of "planet" make sense?
item.itunes:summary: In this week's podcast, we look at the arguments for and against the proposed new definition of 'planet' that would bring the total number of planets to 12, perhaps opening the door to many more.
item.description: In this week's podcast, we look at the arguments for and against the proposed new definition of 'planet' that would bring the total number of planets to 12, perhaps opening the door to many more.

item.title: I Know This Is Not Politically Correct, But...
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Is passenger profiling a logical response to aviation security threats?
item.itunes:summary: Following the arrest of would-be suicide bombers, we look at arguments for and against racial, religious, and ethnic profiling at airports.
item.description: Following the arrest of would-be suicide bombers, we look at arguments for and against racial, religious, and ethnic profiling at airports.

item.title: What Does it All Mean?
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Interpretations of Evidence in the Connecticut Democratic primary.
item.itunes:summary: This week, we examine the punditry surrounding the upcoming Connecticut primary elections to demonstrate the importance of being skeptical about interpretations of data.
item.description: This week, we examine the punditry surrounding the upcoming Connecticut primary elections to demonstrate the importance of being skeptical about interpretations of data.

item.title: Say it Ain't Sufficient, Floyd
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Does a positive doping test mean that Floyd Landis was positively doping?
item.itunes:summary: In this week's podcast, we try to avoid jumping to conclusions that aren't necessarily true as we examine the case against Floyd Landis.
item.description: In this week's podcast, we try to avoid jumping to conclusions that aren't necessarily true as we examine the case against Floyd Landis.

item.title: These Arguments are Not Spare Parts
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Bush equivocates, but his detractors fare worse by LSAT standards.
item.itunes:summary: In this week's podcast, we discuss the logical missteps taken both by proponents and opponents of the vetoed stem cell research bill.
item.description: In this week's podcast, we discuss the logical missteps taken both by proponents and opponents of the vetoed stem cell research bill.

item.title: War on Analogies
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Leaders use analogies to justify military action and sometimes military inaction. Does their logic hold up to LSAT standards?
item.itunes:summary: In this podcast, we focus on comparison flaws, examining arguments made by leaders and the media regarding the current Middle East crisis.
item.description: In this podcast, we focus on comparison flaws, examining arguments made by leaders and the media regarding the current Middle East crisis.

item.title: Money Talks?: Solving the Problem of Terrorism
item.itunes:author: The Princeton Review
item.itunes:subtitle: Does the latest revelation of a terrorist threat really mean that New York needs more money from the Department of Homeland Security?
item.itunes:summary: In the first podcast of the series, we examine the recent call from New York City lawmakers to increase anti-terrorism funding for New York City in the wake of recently revealed plots.
item.description: In the first podcast of the series, we examine the recent call from New York City lawmakers to increase anti-terrorism funding for New York City in the wake of recently revealed plots.
